top_comment.text: what's the point of using the 0 at the end?﻿
top_comment.author: Russell Chase

comments.text:
+Russell Chase the point of using the zero at the end is to satisfy his 
statement that he can measure the circumference of the universe to within 
the width of a hydrogen atom. Without that last zero, his accuracy/error is 
10 times greater (so he'd theoretically only be within 10 H atoms.) Agreed 
that it doesn't change the "answer" but it does change the "error".
comments.author: David Medberry

comments.text:
+Greg Gaven Except when they're using 40 sig figs, the last 0 becomes 
pretty pointless to write out. Haha xD
comments.author: Orionar Ranoiro

comments.text: +Greg Gaven Gotta love significant figures.
comments.author: BChart3

comments.text:
+Greg Gaven What you say is true. However in this video the premise is that 
only 39 digits of Pi are need to calculate the observable universe to the 
width of a hydrogen atom. The number of significant digits does not play a 
part in the demonstration. 

The 37th, 38th, 39th, 40th and 41st digits of Pi are 41971 (not rounded). 
Pi rounded to the 39th digit is then 3.1415....420. Pi rounded to the 38th 
digit is 3.1415....42. These are equivalent values. Only 38 digits are 
needed (assuming rounding, as it was assumed in this video).
comments.author: Scott Dixon

comments.text:
In the video, they said that he rounded up. Furthermore, when measuring 
things, there is uncertainty to the accuracy of the measurement. For 
example, 3 litres is a lot different than 3.000 litres. So the zero isn't 
pointless.
comments.author: Greg Gaven

top_comment.text:
I am wondering if you rounded pi or not because at the 38th and 39th digit, 
you put 20 and not 19. I memorized the first 100 digits of pi and I know 
that the 38th and 39th digits are 19 and not 20. Every website for 
calculations of pi that I saw show a 19 and not 20. I LOVE PI! I am

comments.text: Lol
comments.author: TimeLord Aaron

comments.text: If you look at the bottom it says he rounded it up- I was wondering too xD
comments.author: Arya Kataria

comments.text:
The 40th digit is 7, so you round 19 to 20, which is more accurate than 
dropping everything after 19.  You need that accuracy to obtain the 
precision of a hydrogen atom.  And for the same reason, you must keep the 
zero at the end of the string to distinguish the number from those ending 
in 21, 22, 23 and 24, which are increasingly less accurate.  Rounding. 
 Sometimes it's important.

top_comment.text:
I don't really get the hype of Pi. Sure, it is a constant and somehow 
looked upon as a very cool thing, but what about Tau? Tau has been widely 
used in the mathematics before Pi, and is by far the more usable of them 
both. Pi is only used because we somehow think it is non replaceable.﻿
top_comment.author: Niklas Stenhall

comments.text: Pi hired a better Public Relations Team.
comments.author: Msb Hend

comments.text:
The significance of Pi and Tau from a numerical perspective is identical, 
since they basically represent the same thing. They are both transcendental 
numbers, both derived from geometry, and both actually represent the exact 
same geometry. Tau is just twice Pi.

Pi, however, unlike Tau, has more justification in Calculus. The roots of 
any function satisfying y''+y=0 are distanced exactly Pi from each other. 
That would be half Tau. There are other similar such results. Once you get 
to Calculus, Pi just makes more sense.
comments.author: Saar Korren

comments.text: This channel has explored the Pi vs. Tau question several times.
comments.author: Kevin VanOrd

comments.text: I believe Numberphile already did a video about Tau vs Pi.
comments.author: ascalon132

comments.text:
Pi is easy to know why exists. You want to know what is the circunference 
of a circle? Or its area? That's why pi is here!
Try to do the same thing with Tau, or euler, and you see that's hard.

PS: I completely agree with you. Pi is overrated. But I'm just explaining 
the reason why pi is famous, whilst another constants aren't known.
PS2: Sorry if bad english. Not my first language.
comments.author: André M. Santos

comments.text:
Tau is just 2*Pi. There's literally nothing else special about it. Using it 
only slightly changes some formulas. So amazing .-.

precise is the diameter of the observable universe (

sixty symbols?

top_comment.text:
Pi is famously calculated to trillions of digits - but Dr James Grime says 
39 is probably enough. An extra note from Dr Grime: "Since pi(39) ends in 
0, you may think we could use pi(38) instead - which has even fewer digits. 
Unfortunately, the rounding errors of pi(38) are ten times larger than the 
rounding errors of pi(39) - more than a hyrdogen atom. So that extra 
decimal place makes a difference, even if it's 0." All our Pi videos: 
http://bit.ly/W4oDN1

#scienceeveryday   #sciencesunday  ﻿

top_comment.text: How exactly do you work out the digits of pi?﻿
top_comment.author: TheRhinehart86

comments.text:
+TheRhinehart86 They use infinite series that converge onto the value of 
pi, like pi^2 / 6 = 1/1^2 + 1/2^2 + 1/3^2 + 1/4^2...And a lot of clever 
tricks to cut down on the time it takes to do that, then after theyve got 
to an accuracy they like they stop it and check that value to see how many 
digits down they should cut it off.
comments.author: Ell “christkidz” Op

comments.text: +Geoffrey Wu Better than 22/7 is just 3.142, and easier to remember, too.
comments.author: Tommy59375

comments.text:
+Jacob Nguyen That is a good approximation, but not the best approximation. 
One good approximation is the cube root of thirty-one. The best one that I 
have found (so far) is the 18th root of 888,582,403.
comments.author: Geoffrey Wu

comments.text: 22 divided by 7
comments.author: Jacob Nguyen

comments.text: One formula that I know is that pi/4=4tan^-1(1/5)-tan^-1(1/239).
comments.author: Geoffrey Wu

comments.text:
Head to wikipedia which has some formulas, it's actually really interesting.
The simplest one is 4/1 - 4/3 + 4/5 - 4/7 + 4/9 ... (forever) but there are 
some more complex but more efficient ones available.
comments.author: Tommy59375

comments.text: Take a circle and divide its circumference by its diameter
comments.author: ScottishCuber

comments.text:
By using infinite series that converge to pi. Like 4-4/3+4/5-4/7+..., the 
more terms the more accurate it gets. And there are series or products that 
converge a lot faster like the wallist product: 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wallis_product
comments.author: dekippiesip

comments.text: +TheRhinehart86 There are series that sum to pi.
comments.author: Garrett Williams

comments.text:
+Jordi Foix
Ahh, ok, that makes sense. Cheers for that.
comments.author: TheRhinehart86

comments.text:
I don't know how they manage to work out the large amounts of decimals they 
calculate with computers, but by far the most popular way to do it 
centuries ago was by making regular polygons around a circle, with its 
vertexs actually touching it, and with as many sides as they could manage 
to draw. Another similar polygon was made similarly, in the inside of the 
circle. Therefore, they could state that the perimeter of the 
circumference, which was 2*Pi (if it was diametre 1), was between the two 
perimetres of both polygons.
comments.author: Jordi Foix

comments.text:
No because he rounded the last decimal place up from 88419 to 88420, making 
it larger than all the others that would have come after it and thus 
multiplying by it would result in a larger number, ie: 0.1 > 
0.09999999999999999999 so 100 * 0.1 = 10 and 100 * 0.09999999999999999999 = 
9.999999999999999999 hope that helps :)
comments.author: Theweregrape

comments.text:
It gets rounded so Pi39 > Pi. For example if you round after four digits 
you'd get 3.14159... = 3.1416. So 3.1416 > 3.14159... after you round up it 
isn't pi anymore, rather some number slightly larger then it. So thats why 
when you multiply it by the same diameter its bigger. I think...

comments.text:
Spännande reflektion om inhibition -- ja vad jag har förstått är en av 
kortex främsta egenskaper just att inhibera ångest från underliggande 
(känslo)system. Vi skapar kunskap som gör att vi inte behöver vara livrädda 
för världen...

Vad gäller det obegränsade så är vi ju blott människor.
comments.author: Simon Winter

comments.text:
Ja, jag tror också att matematiken "finns" för oss att upptäcka. Men jag 
tror också att man kan upptäcka den på olika sätt, eller vad man kan säga 
-- lite som Newtons och Einsteins olika bilder av fysiken.

Det finns några intressanta exempel på där exempelvis autistiska människor 
kan "se" mer av matematiken än vi vanliga -- klassiska exempel med autister 
som kan se primtal, ett annat jag hörde om i Lund, med en pojke som "såg" 
vinklar i ett rum han var i, så att han när han kom hem kunde rita upp 
rummet på ett papper, klippa ut det i ett stycke och vika ihop till ett 
3D-rum. För mig säger det att det finns en "enklare" tillgång till 
matematiska samband än jag har. (Detsamma gäller musik för vissa människor.)
comments.author: Simon Winter

captions.text:
JAMES GRIME: We love
pi, of course.
Everyone loves pi.

But one of my favorite
pi facts is--
and I think it's fun.

You only need 39 digits of pi
to be able to measure the

circumference of the observable
universe within the
width of one hydrogen atom.
And that's all you need.

Shall we write out
the 39 digits?
So the 39 digits of pi.
It's 3 point--

now, 3 counts as one
of the digits.
So it's now 38 decimal places.

Let's do the 38 decimal
places--

-He didn't memorize
that, everyone.
There you go.

Show them what you did,
just in case.

JAMES GRIME: Wolfram Alpha
app, never leave
home without it.

-You're not a pi memorizer,
James.
JAMES GRIME: No, I'm not.

And that's another thing
altogether, people that

memorize this pi figure to a
massive amount of digits.

But people who calculate it
using computers, have

calculated it to, currently,
10 trillion digits of pi.
-Go on then.
Let's do it.
JAMES GRIME: OK.
So that would be all you need.
